title: Electric force and potential energy of two spheres

content.question: Nonconducting Sphere <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>X</mtext></math> is fixed in place and has a charge <math alttext="positive uppercase Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Conducting Sphere <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Y</mtext></math> is electrically neutral and starts at a distance <math alttext="3 d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3</mn><mi>d</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> away from Sphere <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>X</mtext></math>, as indicated in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> above. Sphere <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Y</mtext></math> is then brought toward Sphere <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>X</mtext></math> to a new position <math alttext="d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> away from Sphere <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>X</mtext></math>, as indicated in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> above. Which of the following is true of the electric force on Sphere <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Y</mtext></math> from Sphere <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>X</mtext></math> and the electric potential energy of the two-sphere system as Sphere <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Y</mtext></math> is brought toward Sphere <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>X</mtext></math> ?

choices.label: The electric force on <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Y</mtext></math> is attractive and the electric potential energy decreases.
The electric force on <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Y</mtext></math> is attractive and the electric potential energy increases.
The electric force on <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Y</mtext></math> is repulsive and the electric potential energy decreases.
The electric force on <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Y</mtext></math> is repulsive and the electric potential energy increases.
The electric force on <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Y</mtext></math> is nonexistent and the electric potential energy remains the same.

content.answer: The electric force on <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>Y</mtext></math> is attractive and the electric potential energy decreases.
